DEF_BLOCK.FRML: to break open or apart suddenly, or to make something do this:
DEF_BLOCK.EXM: I hate it when balloons burst.
Suddenly the door burst open (= opened suddenly and forcefully) and police officers rushed in.
The river was threatening to burst its banks.
If I eat any more cake I'll burst (= I cannot eat anything else)!

DEF_BLOCK.FRML: to feel a strong emotion, or strong wish to do something:
DEF_BLOCK.EXM: I knew they were bursting with curiosity but I said nothing.
Tom was bursting to tell everyone the news.
I'm bursting to go to the loo!

DEF_BLOCK.FRML: to suddenly burn strongly, producing a lot of flames:
DEF_BLOCK.EXM: Smoke started pouring out from underneath, then the truck burst into flames.

DEF_BLOCK.FRML: the act of breaking open so that what is inside comes out:
DEF_BLOCK.EXM: a burst in the water pipe

DEF_BLOCK.FRML: a sudden increase in something, especially for a short period:
DEF_BLOCK.EXM: a burst of speed/applause/laughter

WORD_BLOCK.IDIOMS_BLOCK: IDIOMS:burst at the seamsto be completely full: When all the family is home the house is bursting at the seams.burst into song/tears/laughterto suddenly begin to sing/cry/laugh: Much to my surprise, Caleb suddenly burst into song.burst out laughing/cryingto suddenly start laughing/crying: I walked in and everyone burst out laughing.
WORD_BLOCK.PHVB: PHRASAL VERBS:burst in/into (somewhere)to enter a room or building suddenly and without warning: The side door of the bar flew open and three men burst in.burst in on sb/sthto enter a room suddenly and without warning, interrupting the people or activity inside: Katya burst in on him without warning.burst outto suddenly say something loudly: "Don't go!" he burst out.

DEF_BLOCK.FRML: a hard, transparent, yellowish-brown substance that was formed in ancient times from resin (= a substance produced by trees) and is used in jewellery:
DEF_BLOCK.EXM: He has a collection of prehistoric insects preserved in amber.
Greek philosophers discovered that when amber is rubbed against cloth, lightweight objects will stick to it.
She combines strong geometry with subtle colors, from muted sage to pale amber.
Favaios is an amber coloured sweet wine from the Pinhao area of Portugal's Douro Valley.

DEF_BLOCK.FRML: the yellowish-orange traffic light that shows between the green and the red to warn drivers that the lights are about to change:
DEF_BLOCK.EXM: The lights turned to amber.
an amber light
The lights cast an amber glow on the room.

DEF_BLOCK.FRML: made of or containing the substance amber:
DEF_BLOCK.EXM: an amber necklace
She stopped at a shop specialising in beautiful amber jewellery.

DEF_BLOCK.FRML: the area below the waist and above the legs at either side of the body, or the joint that connects the leg to the upper part of the body:
DEF_BLOCK.EXM: This exercise is designed to trim your hips and stomach.
The skirt was a bit tight across the hips.
The bars in the old part of the town are frequented by hip young students.

DEF_BLOCK.FRML: an expression that is called out, often by a group of people at the same time, to express approval of someone:
DEF_BLOCK.EXM: Three cheers for the bride and groom! Hip, hip, hooray!
